thread.title: How Donald Trump beat the odds to become President of the United States
thread.title_full: How Donald Trump beat the odds to become President of the United States

author: Mike Kelly
title: How Donald Trump beat the odds to become President of the United States

organizations.name: united states news how donald trump

text:
News How Donald Trump beat the odds to become President of the United States We look at the key states that the controversial Republican candidate won to win the race to the White House Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Donald Trump's acceptance speech in full after historic win Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
‘How did that happen?’ seems to be the refrain of the day after Donald Trump’s victory in the US presidential election . 
The pollsters who confidently predicted a win for Hillary Clinton are now having to eat their words and perhaps re-think their research methods. 
We’ve been here before, after all, with Brexit . 
Even as counting began, it quickly became clear that opinion polls during the campaign had got it wrong. 
As the polls shut, the certainty of a Clinton victory fell from 80% to neck-and-neck with Trump and then less likely than him to win. President-elect Donald Trump speaks during an election night rally 
Key swing states including Florida, Ohio and North Carolina plumped for the controversial Republican. 
Trump even pulled off a one-point win in Pennsylvania, making him the first Republican to win the state since George HW Bush in 1988. 
Trump’s victory was evidently made official with the Wisconsin result. 
The projected victory took him past the 270 electoral college votes he needed to win the election. 
It has been Democratic since 1988, though the Republicans came very close to winning in 2000 and 2004. Barack Obama secured a convincing 7-point win in 2012. 
It has been a devastating defeat for Clinton, who did not go to her campaign HQ. Donald Trump supporters and Hillary Clinton supporters clash outside in Times Square after Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump was declared the winner of the U.S. presidential election 
The Clinton campaign were pinning a lot of hope on Hispanic voters, amid speculation that they would turn out in huge numbers to keep Trump out of the White House. Read More US Election 2016 LIVE: Donald Trump is elected president of the United States 
Exit poll data suggests this did not really happen. 
Trump held on to roughly the same share of Hispanic voters as defeated Republican candidate Mitt Romney did four years ago - about 25% of them. 
He also received as many votes from black people as Romney - less than one in 10. 
Clinton did better with Hispanic voters who were naturalized citizens, getting about 8 in 10 of their votes, the exit poll research suggests. 
She got about 6 in 10 Hispanic voters who were born US citizens. 
But this no comfort to her now and those who fear a Trump presidency. 
The new refrain, after ‘how did that happen?’ is ‘what happens now?’ Share
